holdings.text: Lal-liti lands form part of a taluqdari estate and are taluqdari lands within the meaning of the Abolition Act

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that learned counsel for the appellants is not right in his contention that Lal-liti lands are not part of a taluqdari estate and, therefore, are not taluqdari lands within the meaning of the Abolition Act. Learned counsel for the appellants referred us to certain decisions of the Bombay High Court as to the meaning of the expression Taluqdars estate in s. 31 of the Gujrat Taluqdars Act, 1888, and contended that it meant an estate held by the Taluqdar

holdings.reasoning_summary: Taluqdari estate comprehensively includes all lands once belonging to Taluqdar even if alienated; confirmed by history, Settlement Registers under ss.4,5 Gujrat Taluqdars Act, s.22 jama calculation, and Annexure A

holdings.text: We are in agreement with the High Court that taluqdari estate is a comprehensive expression including all lands which at one time belonged to the Taluqdar even if subsequently alienated

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, if the lands, the subject matter of the petition did at any time belong to the Taluqdar which he subsequently alienated, they would be covered by the definition in the Act of 1949, notwithstanding the fact that when the Act was passed the Taluqdar had no interest

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court view adopted; descriptive sense indicating tenure rather than current interest of Taluqdar

holdings.text: Clauses (a) and (b) of s.5(1) of Abolition Act both have meaning: (a) imposes general liability on all taluqdari lands to pay revenue under Revenue Code; (b) deems taluqdar/cadet as occupant without derogating from (a)

anchor.surface_text: We think that both the clauses have a meaning and purpose. Clause a makes all taluqdari lands liable to the payment of land revenue in accordance with the provisions of the Revenue Code. Section 3 of the Abolition Act abolishes taluqdari tenure and extinguishes all its incidents. If there was only abolition of taluqdari tenures without anything more, there would have been a void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading avoids surplusage; abolition creates need for liability provision in (a), deeming in (b) clarifies specific cases; read together without limiting scope

holdings.text: Holder of Lal-liti lands is, after Abolition Act, an occupant of unalienated land within meaning of Revenue Code s.136 and liable for land revenue under s.5(1)(a) read with s.136

anchor.surface_text: On a careful consideration of the question we have come to the conclusion that the contention of the respondents is correct. In respect of Lal-liti lands, Government made no separate settlement with the holder of such lands the settlement was made with the taluqdar, within which settlement Lal-liti lands were included.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-abolition, in actual possession of land where Government never transferred revenue rights (unalienated); no separate settlement with holder, included in taluqdar's settlement

holdings.text: A Lal-liti holder became a holder in actual possession of unalienated land after abolition of taluqdari tenure
holdings.reasoning_summary: Occupant defined as holder in possession of unalienated land; alienated requires Govt revenue rights transfer, which never occurred for Lal-liti

holdings.text: Saving clause (c) of s.17 Abolition Act affords no protection against liability imposed by s.5

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid saving clause affords, not protection against the liability imposed by s. 5 of the Abolition Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Usual saving on repeal of Gujrat Taluqdars Act regarding declarations/agreements/settlements; does not affect s.5 liability; agrees with High Court

holdings.text: No special contract or law exempting Lal-liti lands from land revenue under s.5(2)(a) of Abolition Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of special contract or applicable law providing exemption; High Court correctly held; proviso inapplicable

holdings.text: No fresh settlement under Revenue Code necessary as prior settlements under Gujrat Taluqdars Act deemed under Revenue Code by s.4 Abolition Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4 expressly deems prior surveys/settlements and registers valid under Revenue Code; Lal-liti lands shown in such registers

holdings.text: Appellants, holders of Lal-liti lands, are liable to State Government for payment of land revenue under Bombay Land Revenue Code after Abolition Act

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the appellants have failed to show that the decision of the High Court is wrong.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All arguments rejected; High Court decision affirmed; liable under s.5(1)(a) Abolition Act read with Revenue Code as taluqdari lands, occupants of unalienated land; no exemptions apply

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that learned counsel for the appellants is not right in his contention that Lal-liti lands are not part of a taluqdari estate and, therefore, are not taluqdari lands within the meaning of the Abolition Act. Learned counsel for the appellants referred us to certain decisions of the Bombay High Court as to the meaning of the expression Taluqdars estate in s. 31 of the Gujrat Taluqdars Act, 1888, and contended that it meant an estate held by the Taluqdar
For the reasons given above, we hold that the appellants have failed to show that the decision of the High Court is wrong.

anchor.surface_text: We think that both the clauses have a meaning and purpose. Clause a makes all taluqdari lands liable to the payment of land revenue in accordance with the provisions of the Revenue Code. Section 3 of the Abolition Act abolishes taluqdari tenure and extinguishes all its incidents. If there was only abolition of taluqdari tenures without anything more, there would have been a void.
For the reasons given above, we hold that the appellants have failed to show that the decision of the High Court is wrong.

anchor.surface_text: On a careful consideration of the question we have come to the conclusion that the contention of the respondents is correct.
